Aleksandr Ivanovich Gavrilov (1891 — 21 November 1919) was a Russian revolutionary and Bolshevik who fought for Soviet rule in Siberia. He served on the executive committee of the Peasants' Section of the All-Russian Central Executive Committee (VTsIK) of the RSFSR, the delegate of the 2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets and the 4th All-Russian Extraordinary Congress of Soviets. In 1919, he and his brother Vasily were executed by Kolchak's White Army.
Biography
Aleksandr Ivanovich Gavrilov was born in Novy Tartas village, Kainsky uyezd, Tomsk Governorate, to merchant and old Saint-Petersburg's metalworker Ivan Stepanovich Gavrilov and Sekletinya Ivanovna Gavrilova (Tikhonova). The family of Gavrilov's father were exiled to Siberia because of revolutionary activity.
Aleksandr attended the village school then worked in farming.
Aleksandr married Aleksandra Dmitrievna Gavrilova (m.name Shashova), and they had three  children.
The Revolution of 1905 and the peasant movement of 1906 led to an influx of exiled Bolsheviks to Siberia. With their support were creating Marxist groups and youth institutes, which grew to party organizations. There also were underground organizations in the village Spasskoe, Kainsky uyezd Ust-Tartassk volost, Tomsk guberniya, where Gavrilov was selling in groceries (on the secret address) of multiple store cooperatives, which owned all the values of society.  Gavrilov was also a student of the Blustein (Blaustein) private pharmacies.
Political activities
After 1905, an underground organization of Bolsheviks appears in the Spasskoe village. Among the participants were the brothers Alexander and Vasily Gavrilov, who became active Bolsheviks.
Starting in 1913, Gavrilov got profession of worker. H moved to Kainsk, where he was leading propagandistic activity among workers. Persecuted by the Royal security, he moved to Omsk, where he worked as a locksmith in railroad workshops. After four years, he got a high-ranked metalworker-gauger. After regular liberation changed his place, while leading his underground activity. In Kainsk, he was a locksmith in a handicraft mastershop. He became a machinist in a merchant creamery in Spasskoe village. Under another last name, he worked in a barn of the Barabinsk station. He worked in Tashkent. He met revolution in one of the Ural factories.
He was involved in investigations twice because of political activities. He joined the Socialist-Revolutionary Party. He was a member of the 1st Volost Kainsk Soviet of Deputies and the Tomsk Governorate Congress of Soviets. On March 25, 1917, after being unanimously elected at the congress of volost representatives of Kainsk uyezd, he was delegated by the volost committee to the congress of peasant deputies in the city of Omsk.
He was recalled by the manual for organizations of Soviet authority. Being a delegate from the Urals at the 2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets, he was elected to the All-Russian Central Executive Committee.
In March 1918, delegated with a final vote of Soviet of Workers, peasant, military, cossack, and Muslim deputies of Tashkent, Sirdarya region, on the 4th Congress of Soviets in Moscow, he was a participant of the Executive Committee of the peasant Section All-Russian Central Executive Committee as of April 15, 1918. In the Delegates, with P.A. Kudryavtsev, he represented the Tashkent Oblast Soviet (Syrdarya region). The Turkestan Soviet Committee was headed by the chairman of the executive committee, Zharkov.

File:О докладе А И Гаврилова по Туркестнскому окружному артиллерийскому управлению.jpg|Certificate of Report on the Turkestan District Artillery Administration
At the 5th All-Russian Congress of Soviets (July 6 — 10, 1918), A.I. Gavrilov was elected a member of the All-Russian Central Executive Committee (VTsIK) of the RSFSR.
After meeting with Vladimir Lenin, Gavrilov, as a member of the peasant section of the VTsIK, arrived in Irkutsk «for underground work and the struggle against Kolchak's reaction». On the party's assignment, he went to Omsk to establish the work of the Soviet of Deputies (Sovdep). He traveled to Manchuria and then returned to Irkutsk, where he was arrested by Kolchak's counterintelligence at the end of 1918 and taken to the Kainsk prison, sharing the fate of his brother.
While... hiding in Irkutsk, his passport listed him as Alexander Ivanovich Fedotov.
— From a letter by his younger sister, Taisia Ivanovna Selezneva (Gavrilova). 1969 He was transported to Kainsk on June 26 (?) 1919, an hour before the uprising. After the failure of the uprising on June 24, wounded in the head, he was placed in solitary confinement in shackles and without water. On November 21, 1919, he was taken out among 13 political prisoners for execution on the banks of the Om River. Instead of being shot, they were hacked with sabers, thrown into a hole in the ice, and then executed in front of local residents. Kainsk was taken by the Red Army on December 1, 1919. The bodies of the victims were recovered by Red Army soldiers and buried with military honors in the village of Novy Tartas.
Notice. The Kainsk Investigative Commission, bringing to the attention of the town and district population the list of those arrested, requests that you immediately provide written or verbal information that may serve as evidence against any of those arrested for harmful and criminal behavior as an agent of the Soviet government or actions against the Siberian Provisional Government.
The Commission warns the population that any of those arrested against whom there is insufficient evidence, and for whom no such evidence is presented by any citizen, will be released due to insufficient evidence of guilt.
Furthermore, the Commission requests that information be provided regarding individuals not included in the list, in order to bring them to justice as quickly as possible.
Applications are accepted at the Commission's office... Note: Lists of newly arrested individuals will be published additionally.

Memory
The obelisk with inscription: «Alexander Ivanovich Gavrilov and Vasily Ivanovich Gavrilov, Red Partisans, brutally tortured to death by Kolchakists in November 1919» was established in Aleksandr and Vasily Gavrilov's motherland, in the garden of 8(7)-year School, village Novy Tartas in 1953. In 1979, the monument was moved and reconstructed during the rebuilding of the new school, located in the center of village.
The executive committee of the Vengerovsky District Soviet of Workers' Deputies, in the brothers Gavrilov's motherland of Novy Tartas, Vengerovsky District, decided to name a street «Gavrilov Brothers».
